channel.title: Yahoo! News: Apple News
channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2010 Yahoo! Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: iNewspaper: The Next iPad Service? (PC World)
item.description: PC World - Apple is reportedly working on a new application for the iPad that will allow users to download electronic versions of newspapers. It could be ready within a couple of months, but will likely be held until the release of the next-generation iPad.

item.title: Will Microsoft Respond to the Samsung Galaxy Tab? (PC World)
item.description: PC World - This week's unveiling of Samsung's Galaxy Tab stoked the already formidable fire lit around tablet devices by Apple's iPad.

item.title: Celebrate 'Talk Like A Pirate Day' with new Todo for iPad theme (Macworld.com)
item.description: Macworld.com - In case you weren’t aware, Sunday, September 19 is International Talk Like A Pirate Day. Along with peppering your vernacular with phrases like “Ahoy, matey!”, “Avast, ye scurvy dog!”, and “Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”, you can honor this special holiday by downloading the new Talk Like a Pirate theme for Appigo’s Todo for iPad productivity app.

item.title: Seven Reasons to Choose the Galaxy Tab over the iPad (PC World)
item.description: PC World - The Samsung Galaxy Tab will be available soon in the United States through all four major wireless carriers. The Apple iPad has already sold millions and has a significant head start on tablet competitors like the Galaxy Tab, but the Galaxy Tab has a variety of compelling features and functions that could sway the decision between the two.

item.title: The Macalope Weekly: The iPhone's a good cop! (Macworld.com)
item.description: Macworld.com - They say love is a battlefield, but it’s got nothing on the smartphone market. Some days it’s hard to know who to shoot at. Consumer Reports wants the iPhone 4 off the beat, but it’s got a job to do and it doesn’t play by their rules! And Microsoft says to frenzied iPad buyers, “Hey, hey, where’s the fire? Wouldn’t you rather have some vaporware?”

item.title: Best Buy: Oops! iPad Isn't Ruining Laptop Sales After All (PC World)
item.description: PC World - One thing's for certain: Best Buy CEO Brian J. Dunn really, really loves the iPad. A few days ago he called Apple's tablet device a "magnificent shining light" that will be a favorite among shoppers this holiday season. And in a Sept. 14 article in the Wall Street Journal, Dunn remarked that the popular iPad has cut into sales of laptop PCs, particularly netbooks, by as much as 50 percent.

item.title: The week in iPhone 4 cases: Kickstands and batteries included (Macworld.com)
item.description: Macworld.com - It's been a couple months since the iPhone 4's release, but that hasn't kept the case makers from releasing case after case of form-fitting, impact-resistant protection for your shiny new phone.

item.title: Find and Redeem Location-Based Coupons on Your iPhone or Android (Mashable)
item.description: Mashable - This post is part of Mashable’s Spark of Genius series, which highlights a unique feature of startups. The series is made possible by Microsoft BizSpark.. If you would like to have your startup considered for inclusion, please see the details here.

item.title: Apple TV Runs iOS, Hackers Likely Ready to Storm the Gates (PC World)
item.description: PC World - You can jailbreak your iPhone, your iPod Touch, and your iPad, but what about your brand new Apple TV? A product reference found in Apple’s iOS is, in reality, the new AppleTV according to The Unofficial Apple Weblog (TUAW), which confirms that Apple's new media streaming gadget is, indeed, an iOS device.

item.title: Remains of the Day: Don't change the channel (Macworld.com)
item.description: Macworld.com - The reason you won’t find Warner Bros. TV shows on the Apple TV? It’s not about money, it's about idealism. (Of course, that idealism is fueled by money.) Then there’s a journalism student who has a bone to pick with Steve Jobs and Microsoft says its next project will be huger—that’s a word, right?—than the iPad. Nothing, however, is as huge as the remainders for September 17, 2010.

item.title: CBS Sports to stream 2010 SEC games on iPhone for free (Macworld.com)
item.description: Macworld.com - Football season is here; you can feel it in there air. And if you’re an iPhone-wielding college football fan, you’re in luck. CBS Sports has announced it will stream its entire 2010 Southeastern Conference (SEC) home football schedule live on the CBS Sports Mobile iPhone app.

item.title: LG ousts CEO over phone losses (Investor's Business Daily)
item.description: Investor's Business Daily - The world's No. 3 maker of mobile phones, LG Electronics, removed CEO Nam Young after record losses at its handset unit. The move occurred a week after No. 1 phone maker Nokia replaced its CEO. LG and Nokia are both losing market share due to growing competition from Apple's (NMS:AAPL) iPhone as well as Taiwan-based HTC's surge in sales of smart phones featuring Google's (NMS:GOOG) Android OS.

item.title: iPad Refresh Due in First Quarter of 2010 (PC World)
item.description: PC World - Despite denials and contrary rumors, it seems that Apple is on schedule to release a new version of the wildly successful iPad just about a year after it unveiled the first version of the tablet.

item.title: MacJournal for iPhone 1.1 gets organization, interface improvements (Macworld.com)
item.description: Macworld.com - MacJournal for iPhone, Mariner Software’s writing and blogging companion to its Mac client, has gained its first major update, which brings a handful of new organization features and support for iOS 4.

item.title: Chinese Form Lines Outside Apple Stores for iPad (NewsFactor)
item.description: NewsFactor - The iPad is big in Beijing, and a smash in Shanghai. Apple's hit tablet computer went on sale in China Friday and, just as it did in the U.S., the device packed eager fans outside Apple stores to get their hands on the Wi-Fi version, with the 16-gigabyte model selling for about $593, a bit higher than the $499 basic-model price in the U.S.

item.title: Outpost 2 becomes first Basecamp client for iPad (Macworld.com)
item.description: Macworld.com - Outpost, Enormego’s third-party iPhone client for 37signals’s Basecamp collaboration service, has received a major 2.0 upgrade. It now includes a stylish new iPad interface, more file handling features, iOS 4 support, address book integration, and more.

item.title: Samsung takes aim at Apple's iPad, iTunes (AFP)
item.description: AFP - South Korea's Samsung took aim at Apple's iPad and iTunes on Friday with the US launch of its new Galaxy tablet computer and an online entertainment hub for movies and television shows.

item.title: 5 Reasons To Buy the Samsung Galaxy Tab (PC World)
item.description: PC World - With the Galaxy Tab, Samsung may have learned from other company's mistakes to produce a computer tablet that can finally compete with Apple's iPad. If you're thinking of buying a Galaxy Tab for work usage, here are five reasons why it's a good idea.

item.title: Galaxy Tab vs. iPad? It’s Oranges and Apples (PC World)
item.description: PC World - You can learn a lot about the target markets of Samsung's Galaxy Tab and Apple's iPad just by watching the original promotional videos for the two products.

item.title: Big Four Carriers Will Offer Samsung's Galaxy Tab (NewsFactor)
item.description: NewsFactor - A tablet that could be the first major competitor to Apple's iPad is now in the game. On Thursday, Samsung announced that its Galaxy Tab will be available through the four largest U.S. carriers -- AT&T, Sprint Nextel, T-Mobile and Verizon Wireless.
